text: <@UN1497LJC> that is for training not for placing bets. The strats that I'm able train on GPU with a CPU guided metahuristic search operate at about 50 million markets per second in back test, that is all custom Simd code mostly written in opencl. The CPU only back testing which you need for more branchy types on RL operate 10 to 100 times slower with the thread ripper saturated as you can't optimise your cache utilisation so well and end up thrashing L1/2. Still fast enough, can train a strat in a few minutes on a years data.

text:
Probably worth pointing out that back testing where you run the markets once to get a result doesn't really matter how fast it is, I'm sure 10mps is fine. Training OTOH where your objective function is a block of procedural stateful strategy code, that is non-differentiable   so you can't use back prop, requires many orders higher run frequency as you are limited to quasi evolutionary / genetic type parameter searches, or even worse some sort of nD grid search. I do the evolutionary thing hence the high frequency requirement of my process.

Or to put it simpler back testing is not the same as training RL albeit both need to run data through your logic and sum up the cost.

elements.text:

Training OTOH where your objective function is a block of procedural stateful strategy code, that is non-differentiable   so you can't use back prop, requires many orders higher run frequency as you are limited to quasi evolutionary / genetic type parameter searches, or even worse some sort of nD grid search. I do the evolutionary thing hence the high frequency requirement of my process.

Or to put it simpler back testing is not the same as training RL albeit both need to run data through your logic and sum up the cost.

text: Only secret to utilise the massive compute in these cards is to understand the data fetch into L1/2 from the relatively slow main card memory ddr6. Shape your data so you can page it in as you compute, shape it so you don't do any branching and you can process data at the core clock frequency x num cores. When you can saturate the card it is very satisfying.

elements.text: Only secret to utilise the massive compute in these cards is to understand the data fetch into L1/2 from the relatively slow main card memory ddr6. Shape your data so you can page it in as you compute, shape it so you don't do any branching and you can process data at the core clock frequency x num cores. When you can saturate the card it is very satisfying.

text: Branching obvs kills Simd architectures so it is best to over compute all possible futures a bit like an extreme version of the branch prediction / speculative execution on a normal CPU core, then sweep up the mess afterwards in a parallel reduction. All the non deterministic evolutionary guidance / decent has to be done on the host machine I.e. not on the card.

elements.text: Branching obvs kills Simd architectures so it is best to over compute all possible futures a bit like an extreme version of the branch prediction / speculative execution on a normal CPU core, then sweep up the mess afterwards in a parallel reduction. All the non deterministic evolutionary guidance / decent has to be done on the host machine I.e. not on the card.

text: Don't fret <@UPMUFSGCR>. I run flumine simulation on a $20 AWS Lightsail instance to generate 'features' CSV's and then train models on Google Colab. My strategies are unsophisticated, so 5K markets takes an hour or so to run and model takes < 10 minutes to train with ~30 features. I've set a limit of 5k markets so I can get results fairly quickly and that's working for me. I take the view that if a strategy needs > 5k markets to make a profit, then it's not viable in the real world.

elements.text: . I run flumine simulation on a $20 AWS Lightsail instance to generate 'features' CSV's and then train models on Google Colab. My strategies are unsophisticated, so 5K markets takes an hour or so to run and model takes < 10 minutes to train with ~30 features. I've set a limit of 5k markets so I can get results fairly quickly and that's working for me. I take the view that if a strategy needs > 5k markets to make a profit, then it's not viable in the real world.

Actually that's a bad example as I made up the numbers.

For back at 100, lay at 90 (fair value) trade, kelly fraction is 12%
For back at 500, lay at 450 (fair value) , kelly fraction is 0.02%.

In reality I often do up to 10% of my bank on bets of 500

text: is that horses? <@U016TGY3676>

If you’re backing and laying then in a sense your bet isn’t the outright bet but you’re betting on your change in EV. Eg you back 500 and (not gonna get the right numbers here but) want to lay at 250, your ev is say double your bet or +1U, whereas if price balloons out then it’s -1U, ie you’d want that trade if probability of hedging at <=250 is > 50%, so that’s what you’d put into Kelly

text: I calculate my edge as the price move in my favour I’m predicting (available price - predicted price if backing), and then linearly scale between pretty arbitrary minimum and maximum liabilities I’m willing to take on that bet.

elements.text: I calculate my edge as the price move in my favour I’m predicting (available price - predicted price if backing), and then linearly scale between pretty arbitrary minimum and maximum liabilities I’m willing to take on that bet.
